title: Intrauterine & Congenital Ocular Infections
summary: Congenital infections have a variable effect on morbidity and mortality, dependent on the infecting organism and the stage of gestation of the fetus. Overall, however, ocular morbidity is common and requires precise clinical recognition.

content.explanation: T: Toxoplasma; O: Other (e.g. syphilis, lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, West Nile virus); R: Rubella; C: CMV; h: Herpes family (hSV and VZV). Note: There are an increasing number of organisms covered by the ‘Other’ category.

sections.title: Congenital Toxoplasmosis: Overview
sections.content: The impact of transplacental infection by Toxoplasma is greatest early in pregnancy. The spectrum of disease ranges from an asymptomatic peripheral patch of retinochoroiditis (often an incidental finding years later) to a blinding endophthalmitis. Antenatal screening for toxoplasmosis is no longer used routinely, as there are concerns about the reliability of the test and no clear evidence that treatment reduces mother-to-fetus transmission.

sections.title: 1° Prevention: Toxoplasmosis
content: Pregnant women should be informed of 1° prevention measures:
Avoid handling cat faeces
Do not eat undercooked meat
Do not eat unpasteurized goat’s cheese

rows: Retinochoroiditis (more commonly bilateral and affecting the macula than in acquired disease), Cataract, microphthalmos, strabismus

sections.title: Congenital Rubella: Pathogenicity
content: Rubella has declined since the advent of rubella vaccination in 1969.
Teratogenic effects especially high with early infection.
Remarkable ongoing pathogenicity:
Interstitial pneumonitis and pancreatic inflammation within the first year.
Virus shedding up to 2 years of age.
Panencephalitis as late as 12 years of age.
Virus within the lens may explain the intense uveitis that can follow cataract surgery.

rows: Pigmentary retinopathy with normal electrodiagnostics (commonest feature), nuclear cataract, microphthalmos, glaucoma (congenital or infantile), corneal clouding (keratitis and/or iIOP)
Congenital heart disease, sensorineural deafness, anaemia, thrombocytopenia, bone abnormalities, hepatitis, CNS abnormalities (e.g. encephalitis)

sections.title: Congenital Syphilis: The Resurgence
sections.content: Having been in decline, syphilis has made a comeback in recent years. The early stage is characterized by inflammation. Many of the later manifestations are direct sequelae of this process. Others (such as interstitial keratitis) may be an immunological phenomenon.

rows: Chorioretinitis and retinal vasculitis (result in the characteristic salt-and-pepper fundus), glaucoma, cataract, anterior uveitis
Mucocutaneous rash, periostitis and osteochondritis, jaundice, pneumonia, anaemia
Interstitial keratitis* (usually presents at 5–20y of age), optic atrophy
Saddle nose, frontal bossing, sabre shins, hutchinson’s teeth*, scoliosis, hard palate perforation, sensorineural hearing loss*

content.explanation: The combination of Interstitial keratitis, Hutchinson’s teeth, and sensorineural hearing loss.

branches: Arena virus with rodents as reservoir
Pet hamsters may act as vector
Ocular: Retinochoroiditis, optic atrophy, nystagmus, strabismus, cataract, microphthalmos

sections.title: Congenital Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
content: Commonly asymptomatic but can cause severe systemic disease.
Retinitis tends to be unifocal, more akin to toxoplasmosis than adult CMV retinitis.
Ocular: Retinitis (focal), keratitis, cataracts, microphthalmos, optic atrophy.
Systemic: IUGR (Intrauterine growth restriction), microcephaly, hydrocephalus, intracranial calcification, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, deafness (may be progressive).

sections.title: Congenital Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)
content: Rarely acquired intrauterine; commonly acquired at birth from maternal genital lesions.
HSV2 > HSV1 prevalence.
Untreated neonatal infection has a high mortality rate.
Systemic aciclovir for ocular surface disease in neonates limits dissemination.
Ocular: Lid rash, conjunctivitis, keratitis, chorioretinitis, cataracts.
Systemic: Vesicular rash, mouth sores, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, pneumonitis, meningoencephalitis.

sections.title: Congenital Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)
content: 1° varicella infection in first trimester rarely causes embryopathy.
Unusually, congenital disease rate is higher if maternal disease is in the second trimester.
Ocular: Chorioretinitis (similar to toxoplasmosis), cataracts, microphthalmos, unilateral Horner’s syndrome.
Systemic: Neuropathic bladder.
